New users

Press here to register.
Once your registration at the Max Planck Computing and Data Facility is confirmed you need to activate your cloud storage solution here. The old project managment platform can be found at http://bioinformatics.age.mpg.de. More information for new users and about this transition can be found here.

Why?
By making use of the already existing infrastructure of the Max Planck Society we are decreasing our overheads - hardware costs, electrical bill, human resources. This means we have more time to work on what really matters, your projects.

How?
Our High Performance Computing Cluster is located in-house at the Max Planck Institute for Biology of Ageing in Cologne.
Our public content is hosted at GitHub.com.
Our private content is hosted by a GitHub Enterprise solution at the Max Planck Institute for Molecular Genetics in Berlin.
Our data is delivered and backed up at the Max Planck Computing and Data Facility in Garching.
1. Once you register in Garching we will be asked if you should be granted access. We will confirm your affiliation and you will receive a confirmation email.
2. Once you have activated your cloud storage solution we will associate your user name with your project and you will be automatically notified everytime new data is available.
3. We will then ask Berlin to send you an user account for the GitHub Enterprise solution. This is the account you need to access your projects here.

Apps
All our platforms are now responsive. You can access them from your smartphone or tablet.
GitHub Desktop
CodeHub for iOS.
ownCloud clients

Analytics

We work agile!
We work together with the users daily throughout the project.
Our analytics portfolio grows on-demand with the needs of our users.
Non-standard projects are highly welcome!


RNAseq

circular RNAs

Methylation

Others

High Throughput Screenings



Software


We develop software on-demand working either on the further development of existing tools or on the build of modules that can be easely integrated with other tools for the generation of analysis pipelines.
More than 90% of the time most of our work is based on pre-existing software.

Examples

AGEpy

Duplex Sequencing

aDiff

htseq-tools

Software for data integration of HT Screenings

slurm-tools

slurm-monitor

Platforms


We mantain and support a wide variety of platforms and work together with IT service partners on the delivery and integration of external platorms at our institution.


Examples

Redmine

GitLab

RStudio server (with HPC integration)

Slurm

Environment Modules Project

Databases (eg. indexed Ensembl genomes, motifs databases)

Galaxy (internal / now at the MPCDF)

ownCloud (IT / now at the MPCDF)

GitHub Enterprise (MPI-Molecular Genetics)



Infrastructure

Our day is spent on the cluster.

Working tightly with the IT department, and strongly supported by our dedicatd systems administrator we assure that no project is limited by computational power or any other type of IT infrastructure.

Our HPC cluster nodes are supported by a distributed parallel file system (BeeGFS) running on an infiniband network. Nodes have a minimum of 40 processors and 256GB of memory.

We make sure that 80% of jobs get started at their respective maximum performance within 20 minutes of submission and 98% of jobs within 3 hours.

Teaching and hands-on-support

We have a lean approach to teaching. Biologists don't do rocket science and rocket scientists don't do biology.
We provide teaching and support tailored to the user's needs. We have an open door policy and guest terminals available to any user that wishes to run his/her computational work with us.

[bit] Sessions - every Friday from 09:30 to 11:30 in Meeting Room 1 (First Floor).

Provider

Register of Societies and Associations

Representatives
The Max Planck Society is legally represented by its Board of Directors which, in turn, is represented by the President of the Society, Prof. Dr. Martin Stratmann and by Secretary General Dr. Ludwig Kronthaler.

Legal Structure
The Max Planck Society is a non-profit research facility which is organized as a registered association. All of the institutes and facilities of the Max Planck Society are largely autonomous in terms of organization and research, but as a rule have no legal capacity of their own.

Foreign Language Pages
To the extent that parts of this Internet site are offered in languages other than German, this represents a service exclusively for staff and guests of the Max Planck Society who are not proficient in German.

Liability for Contents of Online Information
As the provider of contents in accordance with Section 7 Paragraph 1 of the Tele-Media Law, the Max Planck Society shall be responsible for any contents which it makes available for use in accordance with general legal provisions. The Max Planck Society makes every effort to provide timely and accurate information on this Web site. Nevertheless, errors and inaccuracies cannot be completely ruled out. Therefore, the Max Planck Society does not assume any liability for the relevance, accuracy, completeness or quality of the information provided. The Max Planck Society shall not be liable for damage of a tangible or intangible nature caused directly or indirectly through the use or failure to use the information offered and/or through the use of faulty or incomplete information unless it is verifiably culpable of intent or gross negligence. The same shall apply to any downloadable software available free of charge. The Max Planck Society reserves the right to modify, supplement, or delete any or all of the information offered on its Internet site, or to temporarily or permanently cease publication thereof without prior and separate notification.

Links to Internet Sites of Third Parties
This Internet site includes links to external pages. These external links are designated appropriately. The respective provider shall be responsible for the contents of any linked external pages. In establishing the initial link, the Max Planck Society has reviewed the respective external content in order to determine whether such link entailed possible civil or criminal responsibility. However, a constant review of linked external pages is unreasonable without concrete reason to believe that a violation of the law may be involved. If the Max Planck Society determines such or it is pointed out by others that an external offer to which it is connected via a link entails civil or criminal responsibility, then the Max Planck Society will immediately eliminate any link to this offer. The Max Planck Society expressly dissociates itself from such contents.
